Review Title: Striving for Diversity, Equity and Inclusion!!
Pros:
I've had the privilege of being a part of DocuSign for over 4 years, and I can confidently say that it's an outstanding workplace that truly stands out in the corporate world. DocuSign's commitment to fostering a phenomenal company culture is evident in every aspect of its operations.

The company emphasizes openness and transparency at every level, creating an environment where employees feel valued and empowered. From top leadership down to individual teams, there's an evident dedication to listening, understanding, and incorporating diverse perspectives. This open communication culture encourages collaboration and innovation, fostering an atmosphere where everyone's ideas are heard and respected.

What sets DocuSign apart is its unwavering drive for success. The company not only sets ambitious goals but also provides the necessary support and resources for employees to achieve them. There's a palpable sense of motivation and enthusiasm that permeates throughout the organization. This drive is contagious and inspires employees to push boundaries, take initiative, and strive for excellence in their work.

Moreover, the leadership at DocuSign is commendable. They lead by example, embodying the company's values and vision. Their commitment to transparency and accessibility further amplifies the culture of openness within the organization. They encourage feedback, embrace change, and actively support the professional growth and development of their employees.

In addition to the fantastic culture, DocuSign's dedication to diversity, equity, and inclusion deserves applause. The company's initiatives to create a more diverse workforce and an inclusive environment are evident and appreciated.

Overall, DocuSign is not just a workplace; it's a community that thrives on collaboration, openness, and the pursuit of success. Working here has been an enriching experience, and I'm continually impressed by the company's commitment to its employees and its values.
Cons:
DocuSign undoubtedly stands out as a leading company in the industry, known for its innovative solutions and exceptional culture. However, as with any rapidly growing organization, there are certain aspects related to company growth that merit consideration.
One area where DocuSign's rapid growth can sometimes present challenges is in maintaining seamless internal communication and coordination. As the company expands and diversifies its offerings, there may be instances where different departments or teams face difficulties in aligning their goals and strategies. This rapid scaling can sometimes lead to complexities in interdepartmental communication, potentially impacting the overall efficiency and cohesion within the organization.

Additionally, while growth is a sign of success, it can occasionally create a sense of unpredictability or instability among employees. The swift expansion and evolving strategies might lead to changes in roles, structures, or processes that could affect employee morale or job stability, particularly if these changes are not communicated effectively or if there's a lack of clarity regarding the company's long-term vision.
It's important to note that while these challenges exist, DocuSign's leadership and management teams are proactive in addressing these concerns. They acknowledge the hurdles associated with rapid growth and are consistently working towards enhancing internal processes, fostering better communication channels, and ensuring that employees are equipped to adapt to changes effectively.

Review Title: Faulty Processes and Steals Commission from Employees
Pros:
Great product to sell
Ok on compensation (not good not great)
Flexible working
Cons: Somehow DocuSign still has not figured out how to collect the money it is owed from its customers. It allows for customers to access the platform without ever having paid for their plan. Then when they don't pay, they will be sent to collections after a year. Oh yeah! Then when they go to collections, that money that DocuSign is missing from the customer, they will come back to the account executive who originally sold the deal, and take it from their compensation on future deals.

Pros: Had some of the best people, moments, memories, and work of my life. Used to be literally the best place to work and ranked 5th in the world. Helped propel my career and thought I was going to be a DocuSign lifer.
Cons:
Turnover is crazy. Culture has changed. All budgets are cut. No stipends anymore. No holiday parties. 2 days required in office. New manager is insanely arrogant and micromanages. 

Manager tanked a large deal and client said he was horrible to work with and when I tired to save the deal they said they were 100% sure they were going with Docusign but the manager made it sound like they were the bad guy because they looked at other competition as their decision making process. They followed up a response to me that with they wished they worked with me in the whole process, but again, my manager went over my head and took over the deal and tanked it. I was #2 on my team and was put on a PIP that was cut short because it was his word vs mine, and ultimately cut. In the same timeframe 5 other colleagues in my org who have been there for years jumped ship. News to broke out a week later that a private equity firm is about to buy out Docusign. 

This is a sinking ship. What used to be. They’ve lost all their personality and everything that made them special. People don’t come first anymore.

Review Title: Pay no attention to that man behind the curtain!
Pros: Compensation is decent. We used to have some of the best coworkers in tech so some of us were able to really experience creative minds and be a part of some really cool products before our company was taken over
Cons: Leadership is run by boomer board members that actually used a bible verse in an all hands meeting a few years go. People that had been here over a decade were laid off while on paternity leave. About 3 or 4 years ago, we started seeing knowledgeable people get let go to be replaced by offshore or friends of leadership that will never disagree or insist on doing the right thing. Highly concerning judgment in respects to honesty all around.

Pros: DocuSign is a great company. They treat their employees well, offer great benefits, stock options, mental health days, and are undoubtably the best product in the market.
Cons:
Now is not the time to work in sales. Quotas are rising, territories are getting split in two year, seemingly year over year, and attainment is at an all-time low. DocuSign performed extremely well in the pandemic. However, continuing that growth at that rate was not realistic. Stock options are worth 40% of what they were due to management's inability to forecast our numbers.

The commercial org is really strugglingly across the board. OTEs are already incredibly low for market standards - and no one is hitting quota. 1/26 reps in the commercial FinServ org hit quota in Q4 (across all segments). People are unhappy and are really starting to look elsewhere. I worked at DocuSign for two years. Year one, virtually no turnover. In the past 6 months, there has been a ton (and many more are on the way out.)

There is no training program for sales. If this is your first sales job, it's sink or swim.

Our CEO told the company all-hands everyone would be getting raises. In the next call, our CRO specified - "everyone but sales". This really set the sales team off. The MDRS got raises, but the AEs and sales managers did not.

A relatively high performing MDR is out earning a commerical AE. Because of this, many MDRs don't even want to get promoted to AE - it's virtually a pay-cut if you're not an allstar AE.

Pros:
Benefits
Helpful enviornment
Innovation
Decent compensation
Cons:
Communication is poor
Inexperienced managers running teams
Product is behind as other competitors are stepping their game up in providing a better UI, AI and other automative tools
Lacking documentation for real use case scenarios

Review Title: Great Place to work....for a few months
Pros: Honestly, the culture in the sales org is incredible. Loved working with all my coworkers. Your coworkers and manager make you want to work harder. It's such a fun place to be at.
Cons:
"...it's such a fun place to be at." for a few months. The turnover rate is ridiculous and disheartening to know that hard work doesn't mean you get to keep your job. Even when you are hitting your numbers, meeting quota, and showing up every day; in the end that won't matter at all. I bust my BUTT every day and it just does not matter to anyone outside of my internal team. I hate this.

So my question is...what does it take to stay at a company if meeting/exceeding the requirements doesn't secure your position? We hire one new leader and she destroys a department. This is a business so I get it but when are leaders going to start taking accountability for loss?

Review Title: From Innovation to Desperation: The Decline of a Once Beloved Company...
Pros: This was once a place where creativity and dedication were nurtured, where employees felt valued and part of something greater than themselves.
Cons:
The appointment of a rookie CEO marked the beginning of a tumultuous era, characterized by a series of misguided decisions that seemed more akin to a high-stakes gamble than strategic leadership. Within the span of 18 months, the company has had three layoffs, each a direct consequence of ill-conceived strategies that failed to address the core issues at hand. The promise of a leaner, more agile organization has instead left DocuSign threadbare and struggling to maintain the quality and innovation that once defined it.

Equally disheartening is the role of its Board of Directors, whose detachment from the company's operations and culture is palpable. Their decisions, often made in the echo chamber of the boardroom, reflect a startling lack of understanding of our industry and the people who dedicate their lives to it. Their actions, or at times inaction, have not only jeopardized DocuSign’s financial stability but have also eroded the trust and morale of those who remain.

The current senior leadership seems hellbent on undermining the very foundation of the company's image and goodwill. The external narrative being crafted is one of success and forward momentum, a stark contrast to the internal reality of uncertainty and discontent. The disconnect between the public facade and the private turmoil has only served to alienate long-standing partners and customers, who once relied on DocuSign’s integrity and transparency.

The executive decisions of late, rather than being uplifting and uniting, have only served to further demoralize an already beleaguered workforce. Initiatives that once would have sparked innovation and collaboration now fall flat, as the overarching sentiment is one of survival rather than growth. The relentless drive for cost-cutting and efficiency, while necessary in moderation, has been pursued with a zeal that disregards the human element essential to DocuSign’s success.

Pros: if you hit your goals then your in great shape
Cons: if you are struggling, then you will not see any benefits of the pay

Pros:
- Outstanding compensation plan. Best commission plan I have seen in the industry. I have reps making well above their OTE.
- Great product that sells itself. People love eSignature and they want DocuSign. We are better than our competitors and customers are coming back.
- Easy product to sell that a new AE can be trained on in less than a week.
- Great teammates. My direct reports (Enterprise AEs), peers and direct manager are truly great people. I enjoy working with them.
- Fun ERG groups. There's always something fun going on.
- Great benefits (vacation, health insurance, ESPP, benevity, etc...)
- Work life balance is the best I have ever had. I feel in control of my job and my life.
- Support teams are great people (RMs, CSMs, SC's, MDRs). I do feel that they aren't reaching their potential though because of lack of direction from top executives. Frontline and Second Line Managers are great.
Cons:
- This could be the best company in the world to work for but unfortunately there is just so much drama at an executive level that creates distractions. Almost the entire C-Suite has changed in the past 2-years. Every new executive comes in thinking they can do it better but they end up making it worse and falling back on how things were before.
- Executives have a weird level of involvement. It's all or nothing. Too much or too little. It can feel like they either don't exist or they pop up out of no where with a fire drill. 
- The product roadmap has been rebranded with the same content every single year for the past 5 years. There are rumors of a big new product and feature set but I will believe it when I see it.
- There's a lot of female and minority leaders that have left the company. When I started, leadership was incredibly diverse and it slowly went back to the good ole boys club from yester-year. The first club was like a frat house and I guess it now feels like a country club? Either way, it's sad to see so few women or diversity in leadership. This has got to change.
- Layoffs are beginning to feel like the new normal. In 2 years we have had 3 layoffs. Managers have zero insight into this or input into who leaves so it's a shock to all. 
- Executives seem to care more about international expansion than they do about improving the North American growth.

Review Title: Lost its culture and loosing its employee talent
Pros:
- great benefits 
-plenty of learning opportunities
- good product with a huge environmental impact
-Community service impact events are wonderful
Cons:
-Culture changing not for the better
-Lack of Transparency from upper management 
- Setting teams up to fail with massive unobtainable goals
- Leadership focused on results rather then managing 
-Frequent LGBTQ discrimination and targeting

Review Title: Not what it used to be
Pros:
- Some of the best employee benefits you'll find
- Ability to progress in your career if you know how to work it
- Great work / life balance
Cons:
- Unattainable quotas
- Culture isn't what it used to be. There's a lack of team events and bonding.
- High turnover and layoffs lead to extremely low morale
- Unhappy customers and lack of customer care from leadership
- C-Suite and Sr. Management is tone deaf to what's actually happening in sales
- Layoffs impacted several talented, well tenured, quota hitting AEs... is anyone safe?
- First large, in person sales training was held on Yom Kippur (shows lack of commitment to DEI)
- Disconnect on when it's important to be in person. GKO is still virtual but they want you to come into the office for free cupcakes and champagne,,,,

Review Title: Ship is sinking but its not too late
Pros: There are some great people still the company who really care about its success.
Cons: The engineering leadership has made some bad decisions but worse is there unwillingness to admit this and rectify to problems. Second the company has shown over and over that they are no longer an employee first company and that along with poor engineering leadership has led to extremely low morale.

Pros: The pay is competitive at the senior level, coupled with RSUs and potential bonuses.
Cons: The executive team is very disconnected with the pulse and morale of the employees.

Review Title: Need to Kick Out Some New Leaders
Pros: - My immediate teammates are all smart people who get along with each other. - Alot of talented people (although many have left).
Cons: - New leadership team seems to be brining in their friends who come in trying to change things without any understanding of what is actually going on at the working level. There is an attitude of arrogance that is thick. - Completely useless mandatory exercises that are repetitive and never looked at again after the initial effort. These exercises probably costed alot of money to come up with but add no value. - Nearly impossible to make quota. Even if you manage to sell something, there are countless ways they will deny your commission. - Lack of product roadmap. - Removal of NINE paid holidays and the CEO says to "get over it" while laughing in an all hands meeting. - Executive team is making a complete killing in compensation and still selling shares as quickly as they can. This does not send a good message to the working stiffs. - Return to office policy. Why is this necessary? This is not what the core problem is. - The culture that DocuSign was known for is vanishing before our eyes.

Pros: Leadership, pay, culture, hybrid, benefits
Cons: Slow growth due to larger company and several layoffs

Pros: easy work, big company, little accountability
Cons: small motion in role, no accountability cross-funtionally

Pros: Hybrid work model, decent compensation
Cons: Return to office randomly enforced, multiple rounds of layoffs,

Pros: The people, the culture, the benefits, lot's of employees who are happy to lend a helping hand. You can get back what you give!
Cons: Slow promotional track in sales.

Pros: Great product to sell; however, eSignatures have been commoditized, and lower-priced alternatives are taking increased market share every year.
Cons: Install AE is a very challenging position to be in with limited ability for creativity. Go for new customer acquisition roles.

Pros: Good benefits. Aside from that, all the pros set sail over a year ago.
Cons: Toxic leadership and mismanagement. No clear strategy or goals. Cutthroat culture.

Pros: some friendly people work there
Cons: You are treated like a replaceable cog, like you have no value, by c level and senior management. The people who are valued the most are the "sensitive" get offended at even things not related to work or their own lives type who complain about folks they don't like but treat people like dirt themselves. Money is the bottom line no matter what.

Review Title: Really love working here - great work/life balance
Pros:
I've absolutely loved working at DocuSign. It's the best place I've ever worked, especially since I'm at the point in my career where I value work/life balance, while also making a meaningful, visible impact. 
The main pros for me -
Empowered to make decisions about the area I own
Expectation and encouragement to innovate
Work life balance - no expectation to work late or on the weekends. It still happens sometimes, but its certainly not worn like a badge of honor like it is at many companies
Great company culture and expectation for everyone to be helpful, responsive, and kind
Cons:
Despite these cons below, I think we're turning the corner and things will be improving
Cons for me -
Stock not performing great currently
Working on coming out with new products and integration of products, but will take time
A lot of new execs and may have more changes coming down the line
Good comp but lower than some tech companies. To me, the work/life balance is well worth the lower tech comp that is still higher than other industries

Review Title: Great Place to Work and Grow
Pros: The people and the ability to make an impact
Cons: There can be lots of people trying to achieve the same goals but not working together as a united front

Pros: Supportive team, interesting projects, good WLB
Cons: More transparency from leadership would be helpful

Pros:
Collaboration between Product/Engineering and Support has been improving.

Opportunities to grow exist, but are hard to find. It really depends on your team and I've been lucky in this regard.
Cons: The company culture has changed over the years. When our current executive staff took over, they mentioned they loved the company culture and that's why they joined. They then proceeded to completely change the culture, employee first mindset, and started changing our benefits at our detriment.

Review Title: Look elsewhere for a sales role
Pros:
-The managers I've worked directly for (RVP, AVP, VP) have all been amazing human beings and I've made strong relationships with my peers who are also great people

-There is potential to set us apart from our growing list of competitors which would alleviate a lot of pain as a seller

-Pay is decent
Cons:
-Quotas are completely unattainable; about 10% of the reps in my direct organization will hit quota. It's mainly because they have bigger/better accounts within industries that have a higher propensity to buy than the other 90% of the reps and/or they were lucky enough to get territory overcarve from people who left. Just about every one of the bigger deals sold in the org this year have been right place right time situations and have been eSignature centric vs strategic deals/CLM deals

-Zero advancement opportunities. On top of the fact that quotas are nearly impossible to hit, there are virtually no advancement opportunities when you get to the Majors level or above. DocuSign was known for advancement opportunities for so long, but now there's no light at the end of the tunnel outside of just being able to keep your job. 

-Justifying the cost of our eSignature platform is becoming increasingly harder, especially to organizations that don't have very complex use cases. eSignature is becoming commoditized but leadership still thinks we should be able to charge outrageous prices just based off our name

-Sister teams like the renewal management team are not on the same page with AEs because they are compensated differently. RMs are compensated to mitigate churn while AEs are compensated on growth. This causes many scenarios where a RM will do anything to get a flat renewal which often takes any upsell off the table for AEs

-Morale is completely in the toilet. I am working twice as hard this year for half of what I made last year and I know that most of my peers are in the same situation. Everyone is in constant fear of losing their job which makes selling harder than it already is

-Executive leadership isn't doing much to turn things around. It's becoming more clear that the CEO and President of worldwide Field Ops came for a quick and easy pay day instead of truly trying to right the ship and their arrogance is palpable. The CEO laughs at questions during town hall meetings while the president of field ops is traveling to a different country every other week to do whatever he does. They say they're committed to the cause, then sell millions worth of stock the second they get the chance

Pros: Product is moderately easy to sell
Cons: Layoffs every 6 months or so

Review Title: Like any company, good and bad
Pros: decently competative pay in comparison to similar companies. The people that work there are great for the most part.
Cons: the change management strategy and comms strategy is AWFUL! Allan is trying to turn it around for morale sake, but with Jennifer as CHRO that's difficult. If he is smart he would get a more people centric/focused CHRO, she is the core of the morale and engagement issues there.

Pros: The best job I ever had, the best team ever, great colleagues, fabulous and transparent leadership, vision - not a cool kids clique. All before maggie and the board decided to take over and promote themselves.
Cons: Narcissistic leadership in product, terrible HR "leadership", runs like the hunger games meets your worst high school drama. Fake DEI with tons of events with nowhere to go, no roles (resume building?). It is the best tool around and current leadership cannot row in the right direction as they are way too busy giving one another more money and grandstanding while adding to the carbon footprint by flying everywhere on a "look at me" whim.

Pros:
- New CEO seems to have a good handle on future vision and how to get there 
- revamping a lot of internal processes and products to move toward future goals
Cons:
- 1-2 AEs per team are hitting quota and the rest are struggling. Middle management won’t admit it’s because they’ve over-hired and there’s issues with product fit (most vendors offer eSig for free). 
- If you’re looking to join sales, hope you like gambling. For every single lay-off round, they’ve back-filled the same positions. This time, instead of layoffs, the rumor is they’re just firing to cut numbers and not pay severance.

Pros: Large customer base to expand to full CLM platform.
Cons: Leadership disruption resulting in employee concerns about ability to execute.

Pros: I liked it - would work here again!
Cons: Hybrid office environment - better when remote

Pros: Great people to work with
Cons: Promotion opportunities have gone downhill since COVID

Pros: DocuSign is a good product
Cons: New leadership is a tech bro

Pros: All the things I used to love about this company are no more. I used to love the culture (truly, it was top notch), leadership, vision and collaboration. But, all of that has changed and it is no longer the company it used to be.
Cons: Used to be the best company in terms of culture, leadership, vision and collaboration. Our customers used to love us. Fast forward to today, customers are frustrated and don't see the value they once did. The cost of our solution doesn't help, we're the most expensive eSignature provider out there. And while we could justify it several years ago, we can't anymore. As if that weren't frustrating enough, we're now tasked with more busy work than anybody knows what to do with. It's literally taking away our ability to engage with customers and shouldn't that be the main focus right now? Morale is at an all-time low and nothing works as it should which means that completing the simplest tasks is nearly impossible without jumping through 10 different hoops - and no, I'm not kidding or exaggerating. If you're considering a job here, spare yourself and look elsewhere.

Review Title: Formerly Great Company to Work For
Pros: Not many at this point
Cons: DocuSign used to be a place where people, at least in Engineering, were treated as important, and in general people wanted to help each other be better. Now, DocuSign is a place where what gets rewarded is finding people to blame, where management wants above all else to dictate to employees rather than convince employees that their plan is correct -- they want servants, not employees

Review Title: A trusted name brand can only carry a company so far
Pros: Kind Employees, Good Benefits - that’s about it
Cons: Too many talking heads, shifting priorities. No one is accountable unless escalated to. Really demoralizing work place and tough to rebuild trust

Review Title: A shadow of its former self
Pros: Phenomenal group of SCs to work with. Collaborative culture among us.
Cons: Deeply close interpersonal relationships between peers and management level impact entire teams. Multiple RIFs have fractured the culture.

Pros: Strong mission, company cares about customers and their employees. The product is universal and applicable to solving so many challenges in business.
Cons: Sometimes different teams have trouble working together and have competing priorities. There is an opportunity for alignment across functional teams.  While this is the case, culture does encourage working together to find solutions to solve customer and internal issues.

Pros:
- Work life balance
- Great people
- Awesome product
Cons:
- Market is too saturated with eSign
- Pay is not enough 
- Hardly any promotional opportunities

Review Title: I think it used to be great, but I’d stay away now
Pros: Comp was decent. Strong products and name recognition. A lot of good coworkers and some good people in the various support teams.
Cons: I was heavily recruited by DocuSign and sold a vision of massive growth and CLM being the future of the company etc only to be laid off 6 months later. I then saw multiple Account Executive roles posted within a month of being laid off and was never given a chance to apply for another role. The entire time I was there I felt like I was standing in ruins of a once great civilization. Constant shuffling of teams and structure . My territory wasn’t clearly defined until I was 4 months on the job. The prime and co-prime AE structure for speciality solutions was really unclear. DocuSign’s implementation was way too expensive leading to a heavy reliance on SI’s, but engagement was clumsy and difficult leading to drawn out process for customers that really slowed down the sales cycle.

Pros:
Extremely friendly and collaborative environment

Many Resources to improve your knowledge of products and the industry as a whole

Opportunity for growth within the company
Cons: The only thing I could say was that the initial training to learn and understand the product I was selling, at least in my sector, could have been a little more thorough. Other than that, fantastic job.

Pros: Great manager that is supportive

Review Title: Not what it use to be

Pros: A lot of good people work at DocuSign.
Cons:
Here are a few:
 - Leadership is tone death, unsympathetic, and unrealistic 
- Quotes are near impossible to hit and AE’s are expected to get clawback and still deal with inflated baselines for new ops. This causes new opportunities to be worth close to nothing while putting in 10X the work.
 - Return to office with no actual data to back up why we were forced back in 
- Terrible customer service. It truly feels like DocuSign does everything the hard way. We are way too expensive compared to competitors for what we offer 
- Removal of 9 days of PTO this last year with a response from CEO stating it was too expensive to continue these benefits and “to get over it”
 - AEs are unhappy, frustrated, and constantly threatened with PIPs
 - Lack of communication and organization across the entire company

Pros: Love working for Docusign, Product sales itself
Cons: Cant think of any cons.

Review Title: The best company I've ever worked for
Pros: Innovative Technology DocuSign is a leading company in the electronic signature and digital transaction management space. As a Solution Engineer, you'll have the opportunity to work with cutting-edge technology and contribute to the development of innovative solutions. Professional Growth Working at DocuSign can provide excellent opportunities for professional growth and skill development. You'll gain experience in sales engineering, customer engagement, and solution design, which can enhance your career prospects. Impactful Work DocuSign's solutions streamline and digitize business processes, making them more efficient and environmentally friendly. As a Solution Engineer, you'll play a crucial role in helping customers implement and optimize these solutions, contributing to their success and driving positive change. Collaboration and Teamwork DocuSign fosters a collaborative work environment where teamwork is highly valued. You'll have the opportunity to work with cross-functional teams, including sales, product, and customer success, allowing you to learn from diverse perspectives and build strong professional relationships. Competitive Compensation DocuSign typically offers competitive compensation packages, including salary, bonuses, and benefits, which can be an attractive aspect of working at the company.
Cons: The tech industry as a whole has experienced periodic waves of layoffs in recent years, and this can be a potential downside to consider. While DocuSign's performance may vary, it's worth noting that unexpected economic or market shifts could impact job security within the company or the industry as a whole.
